### Linear Regression Consulting Project

Congratulations! You've been contracted by MegaShips Inc. to help them build a predictive model for some ships. 
The company is one of the world's largest ship manufacturing companies, building ships for cruise lines all over the globe.

You've been flown to their headquarters in South Korea to help them give accurate estimates of how many crew members a ship will require.

They are currently building new ships for some customers and want you to create a model and use it to predict how many crew members the ships will need.

    Description:
    Measurements of ship size, capacity, crew, and age for 158 cruise ships.

    Columns:
    - Ship Name
    - Cruise Line
    - Age (as of 2013)
    - Tonnage (1000s of tons)
    - passengers (100s) 
    - Length (100s of feet)
    - Cabins (100s)
    - Passenger Density
    - Crew (100s)

    
It is saved in a csv file for you called "cruise_ship_info.csv". Your job is to create a regression model that will help predict how many crew members will be needed for future ships. The client also mentioned that they have found that particular cruise lines will differ in acceptable crew counts, so it is most likely an important feature to include in your analysis!

- Ship Name

- Age (as of 2013)
- Tonnage (1000s of tons)

- Crew (100s)

It is saved in a csv file for you called “cruise_ship_info.csv”. Your job is to create a regression model that will help predict how many crew members will be needed for future ships. The client also mentioned that they have found that particular cruise lines will differ in acceptable crew counts, so it is most likely an important feature to include in your analysis!

#### What the Spark?! Basics Steps To Be Done

The steps that have to be done are the following:
1. Read in data
2. Transform the features you want in your model to adequate numerical values. *Hint: Start with using only one feature here, e.g. "Age"*
3. Create an array with two columns that you need to train your model: features (= combination of ship properties), outputs (= crew)
4. Train a linear regression model
5. Measure your linear regression model
6. If you only use 1 single ship property in your model (= 2D-case), you can also plot your model results at the end.

The paragraphs below guide you through these steps. Have fun!

#### Plotting data in Zeppelin through Matplotlib

A convenient way to plot in Zeppelin notebooks is through the python library Matplotlib.
Since all our code is in Scala and hence handled by the Scala interpreter (%spark), we need to pass the data we want to plot to the python environment.

This is done through the ZeppelinContext: you first push your data from Scala:
`z.put("some_name", your_variable)`

and then pull it in PySpark from the ZeppelinContext:
`z.get("some_name")`

Caution: Before being able to pass the data into the plotting function, you need to convert the rows of the DataFrame to a valid python arrays that contain your X and Y values that you want to plot.
This looks something like
`dataFrameRows = dataframe.collect()`
`rowValuesAsList = [float(row.columnName) for row in dataFrameRows]`

Below is the complete code skeleton to help you out with all of that – have fun!

paragraphs.title: Plotting the Results with Python / PySpark
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from pyspark.sql import DataFrame

# just for initialization purposes, to make sure there's no other plot active
plt.close()

# tell zepplin to leave the plot open, to be able to draw multiple things inside one plot
z.configure_mpl(angular=True, close=False)

# normal variables can be pulled directly
coefficients = z.get("coefficients")  
intercept = z.get("intercept")
firstFeatureName = z.get("firstFeatureName")

# if you want to get a DataFrame from ZeppelinContext, you need to put it into a DataFrame constructor
predictions = DataFrame(z.get("predictions"), sqlContext).orderBy("features")

# converting DataFrame rows to actual python arrays
predictionsRows = predictions.collect()
featuresList = [float(row.features[0]) for row in predictionsRows] # note that this takes only the FIRST value of your feature in each row, hence the [0] in row.features[0] 
predictionsList = [float(row.prediction) for row in predictionsRows]
crewList = [float(row.crew) for row in predictionsRows]

# plot the true crew values
plt.plot(featuresList, crewList, "rx", label="true crew values")

# plot your crew model linear regression line
plt.plot(featuresList, predictionsList, "b", label="prediction")

# give the plot proper axis labels and a legend
plt.xlabel(firstFeatureName)
plt.ylabel("crew")
plt.legend(loc="upper right")
